title: Eduardo Favaro
text:
Eduardo Jorge Favaro Carbajal (born 26 March 1963) is a Uruguayan <a href="Association%20football">football</a> <a href="Manager%20%28association%20football%29">manager</a> and former player who played as a <a href="Forward%20%28association%20football%29">forward</a>.
Career.
Favaro was born in <a href="Montevideo">Montevideo</a>, and was a <a href="Club%20Nacional%20de%20Football">Nacional</a> youth graduate. He subsequently failed to settle for a club in his entire playing career, representing mainly teams in the <a href="Uruguayan%20Primera%20Divisi%C3%B3n">Uruguayan Primera División</a>, aside from <a href="Argentinos%20Juniors">Argentinos Juniors</a> in 1991.
Favaro retired in 1995 at the age of 32, after playing for <a href="El%20Tanque%20Sisley">El Tanque Sisley</a>. He began his managerial career in 2007 with a club he also represented as a player, <a href="Racing%20Club%20de%20Montevideo">Racing de Montevideo</a>. After winning the 2007 Apertura in <a href="Uruguayan%20Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n">Segunda División</a>, he was named manager of another former club, <a href="Liverpool%20F.C.%20%28Montevideo%29">Liverpool Montevideo</a>.
Favaro left Liverpool in June 2011, and was appointed in charge of <a href="Centro%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20F%C3%A9nix">Fénix</a> on 3 May 2012. On 26 June 2013, he returned to Liverpool.
Favaro moved to Ecuador in November 2015, after being appointed manager of <a href="C.D.%20El%20Nacional">El Nacional</a>. He took over fellow league team <a href="S.D.%20Aucas">Aucas</a> on 23 December 2018, but was sacked the following 29 April.
Favaro returned to Racing on 25 September 2019, but left in the end of <a href="2019%20Uruguayan%20Primera%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20season">the season</a> after suffering relegation. On 25 December 2020, after nearly one year without a club, he returned to Ecuador to manage <a href="C.S.D.%20Macar%C3%A1">Macará</a>.
Honours.
Racing Montevideo
